Thanks for the advice Vincent.  Is this how everyone is doing it or are
the=
re any other suggestions?

	-----Original Message-----
	From: Vincent D.Mur=
phy [mailto:vdm@...] 
	Sent: Saturday, January 25, 2003 5:12 AM
	To: Jos=
h Knowles
	Cc: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
	Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] RE=
ST and HTML forms
	
	
	On Saturday, January 25, 2003, at 01:00 AM, Josh Kno=
wles wrote:
	> Anyone have any tips, or good links, to best practices for
i=
ntegrating 
	> a
	> HTML front end to a REST system.  For example if I reme=
mber
correctly
	> HTML forms can only submit POST and GET requests,
	
	corr=
ect.
	
	> so if the system is
	> set up to use PUT and DELETE do I have to =
put in a
intermediary to do
	> the translation or is there a JavaScript tri=
ck that I haven't
seen yet?
	
	yes.  i believe xforms will allow you to sen=
d put/delete, paul
prescod 
	mentioned this a while back.
	
	with html form=
s, you can use both approaches.
	
	with javascript on the client, you can u=
se an XmlHttpRequest
object (at 
	least i think thats what its called; *wei=
rd* name, why not just 
	'HttpRequest'?) to send a PUT or DELETE.
	
	becaus=
e i prefer to avoid client scripting, i prefer to use an 
	intermediary on =
the server which 'pre-processes' the request
body.  
	approaches i have use=
d include sending the put/delete flag in a
hidden 
	form field, or using th=
e value of a submit form field.  (i
didn't 
	widely test browser behaviour =
with submit field values.)  this
then 
	forms the basis of an ifThenElse/sw=
itch structure which you can
use to 
	call either PUT or DELETE code.
	
	HT=
H,
	-vincent
